comments.content:
By creating an app configuration policy for Chrome, you can specify the exact bookmarks you want to add to the browser on your managed devices. This ensures consistency and provides easy access to important resources for your users.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/apps/apps-configure-chrome-android

"You can use an Intune app configuration policy to configure Google Chrome for Android devices. The settings for the app can be automatically applied. For example, you can specifically set the bookmarks and the URLs that you would like to block or allow."

D. an app configuration policy

Here's the reasoning for each option:

 Compliance policies: These policies enforce security and access regulations on devices. They don't define app-specific configurations like adding bookmarks.
 Configuration profiles: These profiles configure general device settings like Wi-Fi, passwords, or security, not app-specific features like bookmarks.
 App protection policies: These policies manage data security and access within an app, controlling how users interact with app data. While they might control access to web content, they don't directly manage bookmarks.
 App configuration policies: These policies let you tailor specific settings within an app. In this case, you can use an app configuration policy for Chrome to define the desired bookmarks structure and content.

 Compliance policies define security and access requirements for devices, not specific configurations like bookmarks.
 Configuration profiles are used for general device settings, not app-specific configurations.
 App protection policies mainly focus on data security and access control within an app, not directly delivering bookmarks.
 App configuration policies allow customizing specific settings within an app, making them ideal for delivering pre-defined bookmarks to Chrome on your managed devices.

Selected Answer: D
Here's why:

An app configuration policy is a better way to deliver bookmarks to the Chrome browser on Android devices than a configuration profile.

To deliver bookmarks to the Chrome browser on Android devices, you would create an app configuration policy that specifies the bookmarks that you want to be added to the browser. The policy would then be assigned to your managed devices. Once the policy is applied, the bookmarks will be added to Chrome automatically.

To deliver bookmarks using a configuration profile, you would need to create a file that contains the bookmark data. The file would then be pushed to your managed devices. Once the file is on the device, you would need to use a script to import the bookmarks into Chrome.

This process is more complex and time-consuming than using an app configuration policy. It also requires you to create and maintain a bookmark file, which can be cumbersome if you have a large number of bookmarks or if you need to frequently update them.

Selected Answer: A
For deploying an application that contains multiple installation files to Windows 11 devices enrolled in Microsoft Intune, the first step is:

A. Prepare the contents of App1 by using the Microsoft Win32 Content Prep Tool.

The Microsoft Win32 Content Prep Tool is used to prepare complex applications, including those with multiple files and dependencies, for deployment via Microsoft Intune. This tool packages the application into a format (.intunewin) that is suitable for uploading to Intune and deploying across your managed devices. This process is necessary for applications that cannot be directly uploaded in their original format due to their complexity or the presence of multiple installation files. After preparing the app with the tool, you can then upload the packaged file to Intune for deployment.

Selected Answer: A

Selected Answer: A
A. Prepare the contents of App1 by using the Microsoft Win32 Content Prep Tool.

Here's why:

 Microsoft Win32 Content Prep Tool specifically prepares Windows applications for deployment with Microsoft Intune. It converts the installation files into the format required by Intune (.intunewin) and gathers information about the application for proper management.
 Android application package (APK) wouldn't be relevant since you're dealing with Windows 11 devices and App1.
 Uploading the contents directly without preparation can lead to deployment failures in Intune.
 Microsoft Deployment Toolkit (MDT) focuses on creating Windows images, not preparing existing applications for Intune deployment.

A. Prepare the contents of App1 by using the Microsoft Win32 Content Prep Tool.

The Microsoft Win32 Content Prep Tool is used to package and prepare Win32 applications (legacy desktop applications) for deployment through Microsoft Intune. It helps you create the necessary installation files and metadata that Intune requires to distribute and install the application on Windows devices.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription. All devices run Windows 10.

You need to prevent users from enrolling the devices in the Windows Insider Program.

What two configurations should you perform from the Microsoft Intune admin center? Each correct answer is a complete solution.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

choices.C: a Windows 10 and later security baseline
choices.A: a device restrictions device configuration profile
choices.E: a Windows 10 and later update ring

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
Given answers are correct.
Ref: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-insider/business/manage-builds#set-up-insider-preview-builds-using-intune
Ref: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/client-management/mdm/policy-csp-Update?WT.mc_id=Portal-fx#managepreviewbuilds

Selected Answer: AD
I think it should be A and D.
A. Device restrictions device configuration profile: You can use this profile to enforce specific settings on Windows 10 devices, including preventing enrollment in the Windows Insider Program.

D. Custom device configuration profile: Creating a custom device configuration profile allows you to define specific settings and restrictions for your Windows 10 devices, including preventing enrollment in the Windows Insider Program.

Selected Answer: AE
A. a device restrictions device configuration profile
E. a Windows 10 and later update ring

Selected Answer: DE
DE are the only ways I can see in intune, in device restrictions there's no windows update options to select, but can in settings catalog, which is not an option here. 

In custome device config you can use following

Name: Block Windows Insider Program
OMA-URI: ./Vendor/MSFT/Policy/Config/Update/AllowBuildPreview
Data type: Integer
Value: 0 (to disable)

Selected Answer: AE
This allows you to disable access to the Windows Insider settings in the Settings app, preventing users from enrolling in the program.
E. A Windows 10 and later update ring

In Intune, you can configure an update ring to control Windows Update settings, including preventing devices from receiving Windows Insider builds.

Selected Answer: AE
To prevent users from enrolling devices in the Windows Insider Program, you can use a combination of a device restrictions configuration profile and a Windows 10 and later update ring in Microsoft Intune. The device restrictions profile allows you to explicitly disable access to features like the Windows Insider Program, ensuring users cannot enable pre-release builds. Additionally, the update ring policy can enforce update settings that block devices from downloading and installing Insider builds. These two configurations work together to provide comprehensive control over update management and prevent unauthorized enrollment in pre-release Windows programs, minimizing administrative effort and ensuring compliance with organizational policies.

Selected Answer: AE
A device restrictions device configuration profile (Option A): Create a device restrictions policy targeting Windows 10.
In the settings, navigate to General and set Enable Preview Builds to Blocked to prevent devices from being enrolled in the Windows Insider Program.

A Windows 10 and later update ring (Option E): Create a Windows 10 update ring policy.
In the Settings section, under Update Settings, set Enable Preview Builds to Not Allowed to ensure that devices do not install preview builds from the Windows Insider Program.

A and E

To prevent access to the Windows Insider Program, the most appropriate configurations are likely:

 A. A device restrictions device configuration profile: This can be used to set device restrictions, including blocking access to certain system settings that could allow users to enroll in the Insider Program.
 E. A Windows 10 and later update ring: This can be configured to control the type of updates that devices receive, including limiting updates to stable releases and excluding Insider builds.

So, the correct answers should be: A. A device restrictions device configuration profile and E. A Windows 10 and later update ring.

Selected Answer: AE
A and E are correct

A, E proven, update ring can set to not configured in case someone already enrolled
device restrictions. to block access to update settings

Selected Answer: AE
A : If you set Telemetery to required in Device Restrictions, they cannot get preview builds as it needs Optional Telemetery. 
E: Use update ring to block preview builds.
Source:

A and E.
To prevent users from enrolling their devices in the Windows Insider Program using Microsoft Intune, you can perform the following configurations:

Device Restrictions Device Configuration Profile: This configuration allows you to set up restrictions on the devices. You can create a device restrictions profile in Intune to control features on enrolled devices.
Windows 10 and Later Update Ring: This configuration allows you to manage when Windows 10 updates are received by devices in your organization. You can create an update ring in Intune to specify how and when updates are delivered to devices

It is not in Device Restrictions. It is Configuration -> Setting Catalog -> Windows Update for Business -> Manage Preview Builds. This option is not there. So its D and E.

Selected Answer: DE
DE is correct.

Selected Answer: AE
A device restrictions device configuration profile allows you to control various settings on Windows 10 devices, including preventing users from enrolling in the Windows Insider Program.

A Windows 10 and later update ring allows you to control the update behavior of Windows 10 devices, including specifying which updates and builds are installed on the devices. By configuring this, you can prevent users from accessing preview builds, which are part of the Windows Insider Program.

Selected Answer: AE
A. Device restrictions device configuration profile:

 This profile allows you to restrict access to specific features and settings on devices.

 Under "Windows Feature Experience", configure "Allow access to diagnostic data in the Windows Insider Program" to "Block".


E. Windows 10 and later update ring:

 Update rings control which updates devices receive through Intune.

 Create a new update ring with the "Update channel" set to "None (security updates only)".

 Assign this update ring to the devices you want to prevent from joining the Insider Program.
The 30 days represents an upgrade of Windows Version through a feature update not a standard feature update

Custom profile: CSP/OMA-RUI for Update/ManagePreviewBuilds
Update ring: "Enable pre-release builds"

To prevent users from enrolling their devices in the Windows Insider Program using Microsoft Intune, you should perform the following two configurations from the Microsoft Intune admin center:

A. Create a device restrictions device configuration profile: This profile allows you to enforce restrictions and settings on Windows 10 devices. You can use this to prevent users from joining the Windows Insider Program.

E. Create a Windows 10 and later update ring: By configuring an update ring, you can control the release of Windows updates to devices. By setting the update ring to a stable release channel, you can prevent users from receiving Insider Preview builds, which are part of the Windows Insider Program.
